title: Quiz 3: August 2011 Licensure Exam
description: August 2011 Licensure Examination. Covers Socio-economics, Nutrition, Communicable Diseases, Management, and Maternal/Child Health.

questions.question: Socio-economic factors that have a bearing on health include:
questions.explanation: Socio-economic determinants include income, education, housing, and food security. Biological/Medical factors (blood tests, live births) are not socio-economic determinants.
questions.hint: Look for the option that lists living conditions and social status, not medical procedures.

questions.question: The type of immunity a child acquires after receiving measles vaccine is:
questions.explanation: Vaccines provide 'Artificial' immunity (medical intervention) that is 'Active' (body produces its own antibodies). Natural passive is maternal; Natural active is post-infection.
questions.hint: It is artificial because it is a vaccine, and active because the body makes the antibodies.

questions.question: Vaccine potency can be maintained in the refrigerator by:

options.text: Ensuring the maintenance of ideal temperature of 0° to 8°C...
Defrosting... packing vaccines with enough space... opening only when necessary
Avoiding contact with evaporator... lining frozen icepacks in inner walls...
Ensuring the maintenance of ideal temperature of between +2° to +8°C...

questions.explanation: The critical temperature range for vaccine storage is +2°C to +8°C. 0°C can freeze and destroy sensitive vaccines like DPT and Hep B.
questions.hint: The standard cold chain temperature range starts at +2, not 0.

questions.question: Deficiency of vitamin B1 (Thiamine) leads to:

options.text: Heart failure, abnormal nerve and brain function, emotional disturbances
Rupture of red blood cells, muscle spasm, bleeding
Night blindness, heart failure, impaired sensory perception
Emotional disturbances, rupture of red blood cells, nerve damage

questions.explanation: Thiamine deficiency causes Beriberi (Wet = Heart failure; Dry = Nerve damage) and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome (Brain function).
questions.hint: Think of Beriberi.

questions.question: Hypokalemia is a condition characterized by low:
questions.explanation: Kalium is Latin for Potassium. Hypo (low) + Kalemia.
questions.hint: The 'K' in the periodic table.

questions.question: The stage of syphilis characterized by the presence of gamma (gumma) lesions is:
questions.explanation: Gummas are destructive granulomatous lesions found in Tertiary (Late) Syphilis.
questions.hint: The third and most destructive stage.

questions.question: Recommended second line treatment of urethritis in an adult is:

options.text: Norfloxacine 800mg stat plus doxycycline 100 mg BD for 7 days
Norfloxacine 800mg twice a day... and spectinomycin...
Spectinomycin 2mg I.M. stat and doxycycline 100 mg BD for 7 days

questions.explanation: Spectinomycin is an alternative for Gonorrhea when resistance is suspected or in pregnancy (though safety varies), and Doxycycline covers Chlamydia.
questions.hint: It involves an injectable stat dose and oral tablets for a week.

questions.question: The occupational disease that persons working in information technology are likely to develop is:
questions.explanation: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome is a Repetitive Strain Injury (RSI) common in IT due to keyboard/mouse use.
questions.hint: It affects the wrists from typing.

questions.question: The principle of unity of command in any organization is important because:

options.text: The superior is able to assign part of his job domain to his/her subordinate
It avoids divided loyalty since each employee receives orders from one superior
It ensures smooth working at all levels of the organization

questions.explanation: Unity of Command ensures an employee reports to only ONE boss, preventing conflicting instructions and divided loyalty.
questions.hint: One man, one boss.

questions.question: Evaluate these statements. A: 'Theory X assumes employees exercise self-discipline.' B: 'Supervisors should avoid arguments when reprimanding.'

options.text: A is True, B is False
A is False, B is True

questions.explanation: Statement A is False: Theory X assumes employees are lazy; Theory Y assumes self-discipline. Statement B is True: Disciplinary action should be objective and professional, avoiding arguments.
questions.hint: Theory X is the negative view. Professionalism requires avoiding fights.

questions.question: Methods of food preservation which inhibit (bacteriostatic) multiplication of bacteria include:
questions.explanation: Drying, freezing, and smoking primarily inhibit growth (bacteriostatic) rather than killing all bacteria outright (bactericidal like canning/pasteurization).
questions.hint: Find the option that does NOT include cooking or high heat.

questions.question: Match the vector to the organism it transmits:
questions.explanation: Anopheles transmits Filariasis (Wuchereria) in some areas. Ornithodoros (Soft tick) transmits Relapsing Fever (Borrelia).
questions.hint: Soft tick carries Borrelia.

questions.question: Clinical features of typhoid fever in the first week include:

options.text: Pea soup diarrhoea, meningism, stepwise rise in temperature
Mental confusion, enlarged spleen, pea soup diarrhea

questions.explanation: Stepwise rise in temperature (Step-ladder pyrexia) is the classic sign of the first week.
questions.hint: The fever goes up step by step.

questions.question: Progestin only pills work primarily by:

options.text: Thickening cervical mucus, thus blocking sperm
Causing a chemical change that damages sperms

questions.explanation: POPs primarily thicken cervical mucus to prevent sperm entry. They do not consistently suppress ovulation.
questions.hint: They create a barrier of mucus.

questions.question: The goals of triaging in disaster management are:

options.text: Early patient assessment, control infection, determination of urgency of need of care

questions.explanation: Triaging aims to quickly assess and determine urgency to save maximum lives. Infection control is also a component in modern triage (safety).
questions.hint: Assessment and Urgency are key.

questions.question: A tooth cavity that gets close to or reaches the pulp causes:

options.text: Pain only when one drinks something cold
Sensitivity to the tooth when one bites
Lingering pain even after a stimulus is removed
Swelling due to pus in the adjacent gum

questions.explanation: Lingering pain indicates Irreversible Pulpitis, where the pulp is damaged beyond repair.
questions.hint: The pain stays even after the cold water is gone.

questions.question: Growth and development increases in a rapid spurt at ages of:
questions.explanation: 9-12 years marks the onset of the adolescent growth spurt (Puberty).
questions.hint: Think of puberty starting.

questions.question: Primary Health Care activities at the district level are co-ordinated by the:
questions.explanation: The DHMT coordinates all health activities in the district.
questions.hint: The Team manages the District.

questions.question: Activities of pre-visit phase of home visiting include:

options.text: Sharing information on reason of visit
Gathering information on location, need of visit, assembling supplies

questions.explanation: Pre-visit is the preparation phase: finding out where to go, why, and packing the bag.
questions.hint: Preparation before leaving the station.

questions.question: Factors that promote development in children include:

options.text: Good antenatal care, play, follow-up clinic
Birth Order, child spacing, emotional support

questions.explanation: Holistic development requires Nutrition (Physical), Support (Emotional), and Play (Cognitive/Social).
questions.hint: Food, Love, and Play.

questions.question: Arrange the stages in the progression of HIV infection:
questions.explanation: Infection -> Latency -> Symptoms -> AIDS.
questions.hint: Start with acute, end with AIDS.

questions.question: Select the ways to reduce missed opportunities for immunization: (Select all that apply)

options.text: Screening all sick children in OPD
Turning away children to save multi-dose vials

questions.explanation: Missed opportunities are reduced by vaccinating daily, screening everyone, and not restricting access due to vial policies.
questions.hint: Make vaccines available every time, everywhere.

questions.question: Why are people resistant to change in organizations? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Resistance stems from fear, loss of status, habit, and lack of trust.
questions.hint: People like staying in their comfort zone.

questions.question: Arrange the lifecycle of Hookworm (Ancylostoma duodenale):
questions.explanation: Soil -> Skin -> Lungs -> Throat -> Gut.
questions.hint: Enter through feet, end up in gut.

questions.question: Select the goals of Community Health Nursing: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: CHN goals cover the spectrum: Promotive, Preventive, Curative, and Rehabilitative.
questions.hint: It covers all levels of prevention.

questions.question: How can Family Planning providers help prevent Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT) of HIV? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Preventing unintended pregnancies in HIV+ women
Discouraging all HIV+ women from ever conceiving

questions.explanation: Prong 2 of PMTCT is preventing unintended pregnancies. Dual protection prevents HIV transmission and pregnancy.
questions.hint: Focus on planning and protection.

questions.question: Match the agency of socialization to its description:

pairs.right: Primary agent; teaches basic norms, hygiene, identity
Secondary agent; teaches formal knowledge and peer interaction
Teaches moral values and spiritual beliefs
Transmits information and shapes public opinion

questions.explanation: Family is primary. School is secondary.
questions.hint: Where do you learn your first words vs where do you learn math?

questions.question: What challenges are faced by the girl child due to teenage pregnancy? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Teenage pregnancy leads to dropout, health risks, stigma, and poverty.
questions.hint: It negatively impacts education, health, and social status.

questions.question: In a refugee camp Measles outbreak, which of the following are true regarding prevention and complications? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Mass vaccination of all children 6 months - 15 years
Pneumonia is a major fatal complication
Vaccination should only be done if the child has a card

questions.explanation: Mass vaccination (regardless of history), Vitamin A, and Isolation are key control measures. Pneumonia is a leading cause of death.
questions.hint: Vaccinate everyone. Vitamin A helps eyes and immunity.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for resolving a conflict between staff members:

items.text: Fact Finding (Listen to each side individually)

questions.explanation: Stop it -> Listen -> Talk together -> Agree -> Monitor.
questions.hint: First stop the noise, then listen.
